turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Okay, I'm finally ready to seriously start planning for retirement. I'm 35, make about $75,000 a year, and I've got maybe $5,000 in a savings account. Where do I even begin? I'm feeling so overwhelmed.

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: I understand. It can feel like a lot to take in at once. Let's break it down. At your age and income, a good first step is to maximize any employer-sponsored retirement plans, especially if they offer matching contributions. Do you have a 401(k) or similar plan at work? If so, what is the matching policy?

turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Yes, I have a 401(k) and they match 50% of my contributions up to 6% of my salary. I'm only contributing 3% right now... mostly because I'm also trying to pay down student loans. But should I really prioritize the 401(k) match even with the loan interest?

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: Generally, yes. Receiving a 50% return on your contributions is often a better deal than avoiding interest on student loans, unless the interest rate on your loans is exceptionally high (e.g., above 7%). Contributing enough to get the full employer match is essentially free money. After you secure the match, consider a strategy that balances debt repayment and further retirement savings. As a general rule, it's advisable to save 15% of your income for retirement to meet your retirement goals.
